awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: Theory of Computation - New Algorithmic and Hardness Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is developing new theoretical tools for understanding the power and limits of efficient computation. Underlying every computer application, (and indeed computer industry, from networks to security to optimization to storage and so on) available today are ingenious algorithms that utilize the various important resources (time, space, communication) in an efficient manner. However, for not-yet-existing applications (or industries), is their unavailability due to the lack of efficient algorithms that may yet be discovered, or are the underlying problems really intractable, and thus impossible to solve efficiently? This project seeks both new efficient algorithms, as well as new methods for proving intractability. The ideas to be explored by the project use tools and connections to problems from several areas in mathematics, physics and information theory, and promise progress on some of the deepest problems in computational complexity.

On the algorithmic side, the project will focus on a wide variety of optimization problems in which the search space has some symmetry. The project will explore algebraic and geometric techniques to analyze both alternating-minimization and geodesic algorithms to solve new problems for which efficient solutions do not yet exist: these include classes of non-convex problems and exponentially large linear programs. On the intractability side, this research will focus on extending a new method of "lifting" hardness results for complex computational models, such as Boolean circuits, proof systems, communication networks and semi-definite programming, from hardness results for much simpler models such as decision trees and polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

This project represented a combination of ambitious research and educational objectives. For research, the project aimed at making progress on fundamental problems in the theory of computation, the mathematical theory underlying computer science. For education, our postdoctoral program aims to train the best minds to become intellectual leaders, via dedicated mentoring and an enriching academic environment. The outcome of these 4 years of support, summarized below, demonstrate success in achieving these objectives.

Intellectual Merit:

Computational complexity, a foundational core of computer science, has proved itself a remarkably deep and fruitful fountain of problems, ideas, and techniques over the past decades, and served as a driver of innovation in Computer Science and related fields. The research products of participants supported by this grant advance the following diverse array of topics (and others):

  • Theory of Machine Learning: A variety of models and results regarding the replicability, security, privacy and fairness in learning algorithms.
  • Error Correcting Codes: Further understanding of local decoding, including a breakthrough result on their limitations. New techniques for resolving the long-standing problem of rate vs. distance in optimal codes.
  • Randomness and Pseudorandomness: New pseudo-random generators using minimal hardness assumptions were developed, further limiting the perceived power of randomness in algorithms.
  • Quantum Computations and Proofs: New results on the power of interaction in quantum proofs.
  • Expanding Graphs and Complexes: New constructions of these structures, together with new applications for them in algorithms and complexity. Amplification techniques for enhancing the quality to expander graphs.

There were many new connections to the mathematics, including a new relation of the ABC conjecture in number theory to the complexity of orbit problems, connections of topological methods for agreement tests and probabilistic proofs, and the use of analytic techniques for understanding the stability of voting schemes.

A common thread is the numerous interconnections between these and other areas, and ideas flowing between them enriching each other, which were always present in the field and are demonstrated in the annual project report papers.

Broader Impact:

A major goal of the project was the mentoring and training of postdoctoral members to becoming intellectual leaders of the future. This was facilitated by the unique mentoring environment of the IAS, the School of Mathematics, and our Computer Science and Discrete Mathematics (CSDM) program, within it. Most graduates of our program have proceeded to take research and teaching positions in top universities, in which they provide excellent mentoring and education to generations of computer science students, and continue to generate impactful research.

Many of the research outcomes have the potential to impact new technologies and applications. These include the above-mentioned works on error correcting codes, quantum computing, machine learning, and algorithms; all underlying past, current, and future products. 

On the outreach front, PI Wigderson has developed new lectures for broad scientific audiences as well as the general public, which were delivered in different forums across the globe. These include "The Value of Errors in Proofs" (a survey of the evolution of proof systems in computational complexity allowing interaction, randomness, quantumness and errors, and their myriad consequences), "Imitation Games" (demonstrating the power of Turing's paradigm for intelligence in a variety of breakthroughs in the theory of computation), and the Turing Award Lecture "Reading Alan Turing" (on many known and unknown fundamental gems appearing in Turing's paper, revealing the breadth, depth, and impact of one of the greatest thinkers of the 20th century).  Besides the lectures, work is almost complete on two monographs, one surveying Strassen's theory of the asymptotic spectrum and its many applications, and the second surveying the theory of the PI with many colleagues in the past decade on algorithmic invariant theory and its numerous connections to areas in math, physics, and computer science.
